results.title: Does Public Art Have an Afterlife?
results.abstract: Public artworks have the power to uplift a city. Sometimes they end up in a museum, but other times in a dumpster.

multimedia.caption: Pamela Council at a storage facility in Brooklyn, with the disassembled pieces from “A Fountain for Survivors,” a public artwork shown in Times Square last year. Council has raised money to buy time to find it a permanent home.
multimedia.copyright: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Pamela Council at a storage facility in Brooklyn, with the disassembled pieces from “A Fountain for Survivors,” a public artwork shown in Times Square last year. Council has raised money to buy time to find it a permanent home.
multimedia.copyright: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

results.title: Review: Danai Gurira Makes a Sleek Supervillain of Richard III
results.abstract: At Shakespeare in the Park, athletic stamina and action-hero charisma muddy the meaning of a play about disability.

multimedia.caption: Danai Gurira as Richard and Daniel J. Watts as a henchman in “Richard III.”
Danai Gurira as Richard and Daniel J. Watts as a henchman in “Richard III.”
Danai Gurira as Richard and Daniel J. Watts as a henchman in “Richard III.”

results.title: With Sign Language and Sound, an Artist Upends Audience Perceptions
results.abstract: Christine Sun Kim’s poetic and political art pushes viewers to consider the limits, and misunderstandings, that come with communication in any language, whether spoken or signed.

multimedia.caption: The artist Christine Sun Kim, whose work challenges viewers to reconsider how they hear and perceive the world.
multimedia.copyright: Mark Abramson for The New York Times

results.title: Lea Michele to Star in ‘Funny Girl’ After Beanie Feldstein’s Departure
results.abstract: The former “Glee” star will share the stage with Tovah Feldshuh, who will replace Jane Lynch as Fanny Brice’s mother, starting Sept. 6.

multimedia.caption: Lea Michele at the Tony Awards last month. She performed with members of the original cast of “Spring Awakening.”
Lea Michele at the Tony Awards last month. She performed with members of the original cast of “Spring Awakening.”
Lea Michele at the Tony Awards last month. She performed with members of the original cast of “Spring Awakening.”

results.title: ‘Into the Woods’ Review: Do You Believe in Magic?
results.abstract: The Encores! revival of this fairy-tale musical, with songs by Stephen Sondheim, arrives on Broadway with its humor, wonder and humanity intact.

multimedia.caption: Gavin Creel, left, as the Wolf and Julia Lester as Little Red Riding Hood in the musical “Into the Woods” at the St. James Theater.
Gavin Creel, left, as the Wolf and Julia Lester as Little Red Riding Hood in the musical “Into the Woods” at the St. James Theater.
Gavin Creel, left, as the Wolf and Julia Lester as Little Red Riding Hood in the musical “Into the Woods” at the St. James Theater.

results.title: ‘Paradise Square’ Will Close on Broadway After Winning One Tony
results.abstract: The new musical was an unsuccessful comeback attempt by the storied producer Garth H. Drabinsky.

multimedia.caption: Joaquina Kalukango as Nelly O’Brien in “Paradise Square” at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.
Joaquina Kalukango as Nelly O’Brien in “Paradise Square” at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.
Joaquina Kalukango as Nelly O’Brien in “Paradise Square” at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

results.title: A Self-Taught Artist Takes His Roadside Acropolis North
results.abstract: Outside the art establishment for decades, Charles Smith has sculpted his Black heroes in Aurora, Ill., and now in Hammond, La. At 81, he’s getting his first show in New York.

multimedia.caption: Dr. Charles Smith, visionary artist and creator of the African-American Heritage Museum and Black Veterans Archive, at his trailer-house studio in Hammond, La.
multimedia.copyright: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Dr. Charles Smith, visionary artist and creator of the African-American Heritage Museum and Black Veterans Archive, at his trailer-house studio in Hammond, La.

results.title: Bad Bunny’s ‘Un Verano Sin Ti’ Spends a Fourth Week at No. 1
results.abstract: Since its release, the Puerto Rican superstar’s album has earned the equivalent of 1.4 million sales and picked up 1.9 billion streams in the United States alone.

multimedia.caption: Over its nine weeks on sale, the numbers for Bad Bunny’s “Un Verano Sin Ti” have gradually declined, but still remained higher than almost anything else on the chart.
Over its nine weeks on sale, the numbers for Bad Bunny’s “Un Verano Sin Ti” have gradually declined, but still remained higher than almost anything else on the chart.

results.title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Everything’s Trash’ and ‘The Rehearsal’
results.abstract: New shows from the idiosyncratic comedy creators Phoebe Robinson and Nathan Fielder debut on Freeform and HBO.
des_facet: What We Do in the Shadows (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: In “Everything’s Trash,” Phoebe Robinson is a 30-something podcast host living a proudly chaotic life in Brooklyn.

results.title: Imagining an Exodus: ‘Ain’t No Mo’’ to Take Flight on Broadway
results.abstract: The play, by Jordan E. Cooper, is a biting comedy set in an America that offers to relocate Black citizens to Africa.

multimedia.caption: Jordan E. Cooper as Peaches, a check-in agent for a flight bound for Africa, in Cooper’s play "Ain't No Mo’."
Jordan E. Cooper as Peaches, a check-in agent for a flight bound for Africa, in Cooper’s play "Ain't No Mo’."
Jordan E. Cooper as Peaches, a check-in agent for a flight bound for Africa, in Cooper’s play "Ain't No Mo’."

results.title: A Glimpse Inside a Florentine Silk-Weaving Workshop
results.abstract: The Antico Setificio Fiorentino, which relies on looms from the 18th and 19th centuries, has been producing precious textiles since 1786.

results.title: Beanie Feldstein to Depart ‘Funny Girl’ Earlier Than Expected
results.abstract: The actress announced on Instagram that she would be leaving the musical at the end of July, two months earlier than previously announced.

multimedia.caption: Beanie Feldstein in the musical “Funny Girl” at the August Wilson Theater in Manhattan.
Beanie Feldstein in the musical “Funny Girl” at the August Wilson Theater in Manhattan.

results.title: ‘Hollywood Ending,’ a Cradle-to-Jail Biography of Harvey Weinstein
results.abstract: Ken Auletta looks for Weinstein’s Rosebud in this dispiriting account of the former movie mogul’s life.
des_facet: Hollywood Ending: Harvey Weinstein and the Culture of Silence (Book)

results.title: Some Surprising Good News: Bookstores Are Booming and Becoming More Diverse
results.abstract: More than 300 bookstores have opened in the past couple of years — a revival that is meeting a demand for “real recommendations from real people.”
results.byline: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris

multimedia.caption: Lucy Yu was certain that a bookstore “focused on Asian American and immigrant stories” was just what Chinatown needed.

results.title: When a Professor Trades the Academy for an Art Career of His Own
results.abstract: For Thomas Woodruff, retirement from teaching offered the very thing he’d been trying to instill in his students: artistic freedom.

multimedia.caption: At the top of the stairs into Woodruff’s studio in Germantown, N.Y., a pastel of a brontosaurus leans against a credenza — a homage to the Hollywood Cemetery, complete with a portrait of Elsa Lanchester in “The Bride of Frankenstein” (1935) — by the artist Shawn Peterson.

At the top of the stairs into Woodruff’s studio in Germantown, N.Y., a pastel of a brontosaurus leans against a credenza — a homage to the Hollywood Cemetery, complete with a portrait of Elsa Lanchester in “The Bride of Frankenstein” (1935) — by the artist Shawn Peterson.

results.title: The New New Haven
results.abstract: Unexpectedly, the Connecticut city has emerged, both because of and despite its association with Yale, as an affordable and dynamic home for artists of all kinds.

multimedia.caption: Jason Price (left) and Titus Kaphar in front of a former ice cream factory that is now part of NXTHVN in New Haven, Conn. The architect Deborah Berke expanded two existing buildings into a state-of-the-art arts center that includes studios, event spaces and a gallery.

Jason Price (left) and Titus Kaphar in front of a former ice cream factory that is now part of NXTHVN in New Haven, Conn. The architect Deborah Berke expanded two existing buildings into a state-of-the-art arts center that includes studios, event spaces and a gallery.

Jason Price (left) and Titus Kaphar in front of a former ice cream factory that is now part of NXTHVN in New Haven, Conn. The architect Deborah Berke expanded two existing buildings into a state-of-the-art arts center that includes studios, event spaces and a gallery.

results.title: Tony Sirico, an Eccentric Gangster on ‘The Sopranos,’ Dies at 79
results.abstract: A familiar face in Woody Allen movies, he became widely known for his portrayal of Paulie Walnuts on the hit HBO series.

multimedia.caption: Tony Sirico as the gangster Paulie Walnuts on the HBO series “The Sopranos.”
Tony Sirico as the gangster Paulie Walnuts on the HBO series “The Sopranos.”

results.title: Susie Steiner, Author of Acclaimed British Crime Novels, Dies at 51
results.abstract: Her books found a worldwide audience, but while she wrote them she had to contend with the loss of her sight and the diagnosis of a brain tumor.

multimedia.caption: The author Susie Steiner, whose Manon Bradshaw detective novels became popular both in England and abroad, in an undated photo.
The author Susie Steiner, whose Manon Bradshaw detective novels became popular both in England and abroad, in an undated photo.
The author Susie Steiner, whose Manon Bradshaw detective novels became popular both in England and abroad, in an undated photo.

results.title: At BroadwayCon, Hillary Clinton Celebrates Women in the Theater
results.abstract: The former secretary of state moderated a discussion on Friday afternoon about successes and barriers for women working in the theater.

multimedia.caption: Hillary Clinton, center, with, from left, LaChanze, Donna Murphy and Vanessa Williams at the Manhattan Center on Friday afternoon.
Hillary Clinton, center, with, from left, LaChanze, Donna Murphy and Vanessa Williams at the Manhattan Center on Friday afternoon.

results.title: Remembering James Caan and His Potent Mix of Swagger and Delicacy
results.abstract: “The Godfather” helped open up a range of roles for the actor that allowed him to play against type and expectation in wonderful ways.

multimedia.caption: James Caan’s career may have risen and fallen, but he brought a greatness to it overall.
James Caan’s career may have risen and fallen, but he brought a greatness to it overall.

results.abstract: Addiction, fatherhood and transgender identity in new books by Cindy House, Will Jawando and Diana Goetsch.

results.title: ‘He Presented Another Path’: Actors and Directors on Peter Brook
results.abstract: Patrick Stewart, Tarell Alvin McCraney, Tina Landau and Tim Robbins on being challenged and inspired by the legendary theater maker, who died last weekend.

multimedia.caption: Marcello Magni and Kathryn Hunter in “Why?,” a play co-written and co-directed by Peter Brook at Theater for a New Audience in 2019. “He allowed us a journey,” Magni said.

results.title: Grime Transformed British Music. A New Exhibition Traces How.
results.abstract: “Grime Stories: From the Corner to the Mainstream” at the Museum of London highlights the 20-year-old history and far-reaching impact of the British rap genre.
des_facet: Grime Stories: From the Corner to the Mainstream (Exhibit)

multimedia.caption: Jammer, a pioneering grime M.C., at “Grime Stories: From the Corner to the Mainstream,” a new exhibition exploring the history of the British rap genre in East London.

results.title: Larry Storch, Comic Actor Best Known for ‘F Troop,’ Dies at 99
results.abstract: His well-honed comic timing, and the mimicry skills he had developed in nightclubs, served him well on one of the sillier sitcoms of the 1960s.

multimedia.caption: Larry Storch had a long career on the stage and screen, but his other work was dwarfed by the impression he made on the sitcom “F Troop.”
multimedia.copyright: ABC Photo Archives/Disney via Getty Images

results.title: Director of the Guggenheim to Step Down
results.abstract: Richard Armstrong, whose 14-year tenure was shaped by staff complaints of racism, labor issues and a public outcry over a planned offshoot in Abu Dhabi, said he will leave the museum in 2023.

multimedia.caption: “The board is rejuvenated, and active — it’s a good moment,” Richard Armstrong told The Financial Times of his stepping down.
“The board is rejuvenated, and active — it’s a good moment,” Richard Armstrong told The Financial Times of his stepping down.
“The board is rejuvenated, and active — it’s a good moment,” Richard Armstrong told The Financial Times of his stepping down.

results.title: ‘Trigger Point’ Review: Pure Pressure à la ‘Line of Duty’
results.abstract: A new Peacock series about a London bomb squad bears the mark of its showrunner, Jed Mercurio, Britain’s master of the crime melodrama.

multimedia.caption: Adrian Lester and Vicky McClure are crack bomb-disposal specialists in “Trigger Point,” a British thriller arriving Friday on Peacock.
Adrian Lester and Vicky McClure are crack bomb-disposal specialists in “Trigger Point,” a British thriller arriving Friday on Peacock.

results.title: At the Opera, Humans Bear Witness to Atrocity, or Ignore It
results.abstract: Whether in works by Mahler, Mozart or Rossini, directors at the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France evoke mass death and refugee crises.

multimedia.caption: Romeo Castellucci’s staging of Mahler’s “Resurrection” Symphony at the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France is a prolonged exhumation of bodies from a shallow mass grave.
Romeo Castellucci’s staging of Mahler’s “Resurrection” Symphony at the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France is a prolonged exhumation of bodies from a shallow mass grave.
Romeo Castellucci’s staging of Mahler’s “Resurrection” Symphony at the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France is a prolonged exhumation of bodies from a shallow mass grave.

results.title: Kenward Elmslie, Poet and Librettist, Dies at 93
results.abstract: He collaborated on operas with Jack Beeson and Ned Rorem and published numerous poetry books. Late in life, he was victimized by theft.

multimedia.caption: Kenward Elmslie in 1975. He was plugged into the New York art and literary scene and wrote opera librettos, songs and poetry.
Kenward Elmslie in 1975. He was plugged into the New York art and literary scene and wrote opera librettos, songs and poetry.

results.title: Zawe Ashton Isn’t Here to Be a Victim of Your Projections
results.abstract: The actress was never offered a period piece until “Mr. Malcolm’s List.” She was given 24 hours to decide whether to do it. Now she’s earning raves.

multimedia.caption: “The reality is you can be acting for a long time and not be called to that table,” Zawe Ashton said of the lack of diversity in period dramas.
multimedia.copyright: Heather Sten for The New York Times
